value: This is a pathological breast H&E slide.
name: root

children.value: There are aggressive cancerous lesions in which cancer cells are invading neighboring tissues.
children.name: Invasive

children.value: There are no lesions or the lesions show non-invasive and the cancer cells are not invading other tissues.
children.name: Non-invasive

children.value: The lesions show non-atypical, which is a benign type of non-cancerous disease.
children.name: Non-atypical

children.value: No cancer was found in the lesions.
children.name: Normal

children.value: The lesions show hyperplasia, an excessive growth of cells, but are not cancerous.
children.name: Hyperplastic

children.value: There are benign lesions such as cysts and fibroadenoma, not cancer.
children.name: Benign

children.value: The lesions show usual ductal hyperplasia, in which cells within the breast ducts proliferate but maintain normal arrangement and structure.
children.name: UDH

children.value: The lesions show possible precancerous conditions or ductal carcinoma in situ, which is a non-invasive form of breast cancer.
children.name: Atypical or DCIS

children.value: The lesions show atypical, and their cells show a different morphology and structure from normal breast cells, but the degree of change is not enough to be diagnosed as cancer, which is a precancerous state.
children.name: Atypical

children.value: The lesions show atypical ductal hyperplasia, which mainly occurs in breast ducts. Its cell characteristics are similar to ductal carcinoma in situ, but the number and range of cells are not as large as ductal carcinoma in situ.
children.name: ADH

children.value: The lesions show flat epithelial atypia, which is a milder form of atypical cell hyperplasia, and their cell changes are limited to the flat epithelium of the lobules and are accompanied by slight cellular atypia, but it is not as obvious as atypical ductal hyperplasia.
children.name: FEA

children.value: The lesions show ductal carcinoma in situ, which is non-invasive breast cancer, and their cancer cells are confined within the breast ducts and have not yet penetrated the duct walls and invaded surrounding normal tissue.
children.name: DCIS
